title: Introduction to BARK 2008

author: Neil D. Lawrence, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield

segmentation: Welcome for the second time to the Bayesian Research kitchen, I thought.
Just as a start, I would give you a bit of background.
Actually there aren't any arrangements anymore, but I'll give you a bit of background to the meeting and.
The meetings that have gone before, so this is, I think, the 4th.
We were just discussing a breakfast meeting in this sort of series, but it's also part of a thematic program, Pascal, to thematic program on leveraging complex prior knowledge.
So that's something Bayesians should be good at now.
The history of this workshop is that there was a sparse GP workshop organized very informal thing organized by Chris in Edinburgh, which I think about 10 of us there something like that.
I remember at the end Manfred Opper said we should do things like this more often, so.
When I had a bit of spare cash, we did a Gaussian process roundtable in June 2005 and that was very energetic and lively and lots of progress.
Now what I'm taken going to show you next was what the perspective was at the beginning of that workshop.
So Chris said when we were arguing about these things, it's a little bit like Monty Python.
So at the I think what he was referring to is this from the Life of Brian, which is never used this.
This was the intro for the party two years ago.
So this is the scene.
The Life of Brian where Brian comes in and says are you the Judean People's front?
So this is sort of all set in Israel and read who was played by John.
Please tell him to fuck off.
And Brian said I didn't want to sell this stuff, it's only job.
I hate the Romans as much as anyone and read says the Judean People's Front where the people front of Judea Judean peoples front core.
Can I join your group?
Listen if you want to join the people front of Judea, you do have really hate the Romans.
I do.
Oh yeah, how much a lot right urine listen.
The only people we hate more than the Romans or the fucking Judy NP.
Front, OK, so this is the life of a research student.
So you receive a group of statisticians and walk up to them and you say, are you frequently statisticians?
This is Chris Williams.
Here is it's Prof. And then the student says I didn't want to research this stuff.
It's only a job.
I hate fuzzy logic as much as anybody.
Frequentist statisticians, we're Bayesian statisticians.
Can I join your group?
Listen, if you really want to join the Bayesians, have to really hate fuzzy logic.
I do.
Oh yeah, how much a lot right?
Urine listen.
The only thing we ate more than fuzzy logic is that fucking frequentists.
OK, so the worry then and this again is pizza slice directly taken from that intro.
So the why then was Gaussian processes machine learning and I was worried that they would end up like Beta Max in video right?
Because they seemed a much better technical specification and did survivors like a professional artists format?
But VHS basically took over all this stuff sort of dead now.
But the point is there that.
Don't want to be like Beta Max?
So I think that's a beta Max tape I found on the web.
So how could we get people to stop using SVM and stuff?
Using GPS was the question.
And these were just a couple of issues now.
I think if I've got the.
Web browser app.
One of the nice things.
So what's the story?
Did we succeed?
Is the question I guess.
So I'm going to claim we did.
This is my evidence based on my TL this year, sparse, multiscale Gaussian process regression, while the Christian Kim Kwang in and Chill cop Bernard.
Job done.
So I should say that I've used that joke twice.
He's probably get really pissed off with me for keeping on pointing out now on video.
Is a Gaussian process so well?
I don't think.
I mean, it's a joke, but it is.
Also, it's true that there's a lot of interesting Gaussian process.
A lot of that is brought about by Carl increases book, but I think the nice thing is there's also the methods there to make them practical.
Some of the problems we saw a few years ago there anymore.
And really, it's a tool that I think we understand and we can promote and a lot of people becoming interested in.
So I think in some sense we can see that as a successful work.
But what are today's issues?
So I sort of feel that.
That movement was successful, but what do we have to worry about now?
Well, the workshop themes for this workshop.
I love them, recovered nicely yesterday.
I mean, I think that there's this interesting thing about science versus engineering, which you can also talk about as black box versus sort of.
I mean there's a parallel with the idea of black box versus Bayesian statistician.
If you're really looking for the truth, then you really have to do a Bayesian inference and everything correctly and have no a lot about your models.
And that's one way of doing things.
But if you're just looking for performance on something, then you can have the wrong model.
You can have approximate inference, and you can do better than other people.
Carlos said, well, we're spending all this time on inference, but why did he probably?
Wasn't saying quite that.
But the thing I think of is we separate in Bayesian inference.
We separate inference from decision, and I don't think that's necessarily a good idea if the model is wrong, there's a problem of model miss.
Match.
I've got a big worry actually, because I think where the worry is now different.
My worry is different.
What we saw with them.
The party is worried that people weren't taking up these methods that we thought they should take up, and now I think that is happening, so I'm not as worried Zubin was by that.
I sort of feel that it's inevitable that will keep growing and growing snowballing, but my worry is slightly different.
So Phil David was at Joshua Taylor's inaugural lecture.
He gave a talk and he said this thing that when they started in UCL in the 70s in statistics with Bayesian inference and Bayesian approaches, it was like being in a jungle.
There were like very few of them, and they were like hacking through this sort of nasty terrain where everyone was criticizing them and he said it's very strange to be in.

Bayesian inference today because now he sees the same territory and it's all being farmed and there are tractors and plows and basically that that feeling of being at the forefront and breaking ground isn't there so much because so much of what they were pushing in those days is now widely accepted.
The Bayesian framework, I think is extremely powerful.

I'm much more powerful than any of the alternative, but one of the worries I have and I don't know if these are shared is are we so excited about the things that the Bayesian framework can do I it's so much better than its competitors that were not paying enough attention to the things it can't do.

An looking beyond bays, and maybe we should be trying to get back to that jungle area again and saying, OK, so we've achieved most of the things that certainly in terms of if I have a Bayesian statistical problem in science, I know how to go.
The approach I might not have all the tools and algorithms.
To do deal with it, but I know how to deal with the approach.
I know how to prove that one model is better than the other.
I have to create a model.
I have to specify the probabilistically.
I can do sampling to try and specify.
It might be difficult, but I know the framework.
But is that the right framework for doing black box machine learning in general?

And I think we need to be really self questioning all the time because I think we can end up being victims of the success of the Bayesian framework and I think we need to keep analyzing what we're doing and thinking of going beyond it.
That's sort of personal.
Opinion so as I say, the workshop is all past of Pascal thematic program and I wanted to make sure I did.
Forget to thank both Pascal two and Microsoft Research who gave it additional funding for funding the workshop so that you're all here.
OK, so.
Format of the workshop.
I've written down that is 45 minute talk followed by 15 minute discussion.
What it really means is I want the speaker to have 45 minutes of material, so it doesn't mean that you shouldn't be questioning the speaker during the talk.
Will try and keep the discussion going as it was for Zubin's talk last night.
Are there any questions?
You know?
Good, I also have two menus which people haven't filled in for their dinner tonight.
You won't eat tonight unless you fill in your menu choices.
This one.
Anyone else?
Nope.
It was someone else at Marks Table no, no.
So you need to fill these in so that they can cook the right food for you this evening, so they believe they've got one missing, OK?
Right?
OK, so that's about it for the introduction that I said.
Are there any questions?
So even did you fill in your dinner menu thing you did good?
I have a question you were talking about switching the walk to yeah.
OK, so that's yeah thanks for mentioning that.
I think the reason I think we won't do that is because I think some speakers have been relying on a period of time.
Finish their talk.
When the idea was mentioned, some people went.
And as well As for the local war this afternoon.
We're not going to plan anything in an organized large group way, so feel free to plan your own walk or there are things to visit locally, like Wordsworth's Cottage Dove Cottage.
I think it's called where a famous British poet spent his time writing poems.
And I think there's also Beatrix Potter who how many people per Beatrix Potter part from the Brits?
No yeah yeah.
Good are good.
So she also lived up here and there's a cottage there.
So there are other things and ask at reception.
They'll have plenty of things.
There's a swimming pool.
We can organize a group swimming races or something like that.
OK.
So any other questions?
Good so.
Manfred, do you want to come up?
I'll hand over to the first speaker.
